Search for a Single Reptile Species in The Reptile Database (RDB)

Source: R/reptSearch.R
reptSearch.Rd

Queries The Reptile Database (RDB) for information about a single reptile species using its binomial name.

reptSearch(binomial=NULL, getRef=FALSE, verbose=TRUE)

Arguments

binomial

Character string. The valid binomial name of a reptile species (e.g., "Boa constrictor").

getRef

Logical. If TRUE, returns the list of references from RDB associated with the species. Default is FALSE.

verbose

Logical. If TRUE, prints species information in the console. Default is TRUE.

Value

A list containing species information retrieved from The Reptile Database. If getRef = TRUE, returns references related to the species.

References

Uetz, P., Freed, P., & Hošek, J. (Eds.). (2025). The Reptile Database. Retrieved from http://www.reptile-database.org

See also

reptSynonyms, reptSpecies for related species data functions.

Examples

# \donttest{
reptSearch("Boa constrictor")

#> Distribution:
#>  - Colombia (Valle del Cauca), Venezuela (Merida [HR 27: 88], Isla Margarita), Guyana, French French Guiana, Suriname, Peru (Pasco etc.), Bolivia, Brazil (Amapá, Pará, Rondonia, Roraima, Bahia, Sergipe, RO, Amazonas, Pará, Pernambuco, Paraíba, Distrito Federal, São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, Paraná, Piauí, Mato Grosso, Goiás, S Ceará, Rio Grande do Norte), Argentina, Paraguay

#>  - atlantica: Brazil (Rio de Janeiro, Espírito Santo) 
#>  - constrictor: Type locality: “Indiis”

#>  - longicauda: N Peru; Type locality: region around Tumbes, Tumbes Province, N Peru.

#>  - Holotype: unlocated fide McDiarmid et al., 1999, Reynolds & Henderson 2018) [occidentalis] 
#> 
#> Diagnosis:
#>  - Diagnosis (constrictor in Honduras): “Boa constrictor differs from all other Honduran snakes by the combination of having enlarged ventral scales that do not extend the entire width of the venter, no enlarged scales on the top of the head, mostly entire subcaudal scales, smooth dorsal scales in more than 60 rows at midbody, a huge adult size, and in lacking labial pits.” (McCranie 2011: 61) 
#>  - Unfortunately we had to temporarily remove additional information as this was scraped by multiple AI companies who sell that data to their customers. These details, e.g. detailed descriptions or comparisons (about 3414 characters) are available for collaborators and contributors. Please contact us for details. 
#> 
#> Comment:
#>  - Synonymy: Boa constrictor melanogaster Langhammer 1983 is a nomen dubium fide Price & Russo 1991. It’s type locality is “Ecuador, Morona-Santiago, nr. Río Yaupi Catholic Mission, upstream from Ró Santiago, Jivaro Indians, Holotype: UMMZ. Synonymy partly after STIMSON 1969. We follow Reynolds (2025) in recognizing B. atlantica as a synonym or subspecies of B. constrictor, given the poor documentation and justification in Gonzalez et al. 2024. 
#>  - Subspecies: Hynková et al. (2010) and others suggested that B. c. imperator may be a full species. If so, they also suggested that it would comprise all populations of the Central American clade, including B. c. sabogae and B. c. longicauda. Hynkova et al. found no molecular support for the distinction between the nominotypic subspecies and B. c. amarali. Hynkova et al. did not analyze all (sub-) species, e.g. orophias or nebulosa. If B. atlantica is treated as species, B. occidentalis needs to be treated as species too. However, both could be treated as subspecies of B. constrictor too. See phylogeny in Gonzalez et al. 2024. 
#>  - Crother et al. (2009) have found a snake shed in Manitoba, Canada, which was identified by DNA sequencing as most likely coming from Boa constrictor. 
#>  - Genome: The Boa constrictor genome has been sequenced by Vicoso et al. (2013). 
#>  - Distribution: B. c. constrictor s.l. only occurs in South America; all other reports from Central America and the Caribbean represent subspecies (now other species). Hence not anymore in Mexico (Tamaulipas, Quéretaro, Veracruz, Puebla, Jalisco, Hidalgo), Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama. Not in Yucatan state (Mexico), fide Gonzalez-Sanchez et al. 2017. See maps in Bonny 2007. Distribution: Not listed for San Luis Potosí by Lemos-Espinal et al. 2018 (checklist SLP). Not in Morelos fide Lemos-Espinal 2020 (where it is replaced by B. sigma). See also map in Nogueira et al. 2019 for South America. See map in Gonzalez et al. 2024 for map of B. atlantica. 
#>  - Relative abundance in Honduras: rare 
#>  - Type species: Boa constrictor LINNAEUS 1758: 215 is the type species of the genus Boa LINNAEUS 1758: 214. 
#>  - Type genus. Boa Linnaeus 1758 is the type genus of the family Boidae (sensu Pyron et al. 2014). The famly (sensu Pyron et al. 2014) contains the following genera: Boa, Chilabothrus, Corallus, Epicrates, Eunectes. 
#>  - Karyotypes: Viana et al. 2020 present karyotypes for Boa constrictor and other boids. 
#>  - Habitat: partly arboreal (Harrington et al. 2018). 
#>  - Extinct species (genus Boa): B. blanchardensis Bochaton & Bailon 2018 
#>  - Chresonymy (atlantica): after Gonzalez et al. 2024, see there also for references. 
#>  - NCBI taxonID: 499170 [occidentalis] 
#> 
#> Etymology:
#>  - Named after the Latin word constrictus, meaning "to constrict or contract." 
#>  - B. c. atlantica was named after the Atlantic coast but mainly the Atlantic Forest ecoregion, the homeland of several endemic species, including this new Boa. 
#>  - B. c. longicauda was apparently named after its long tail, from Latin cauda = tail. 
#>  - B. c. ortonii was named after Named after Prof. James Orton, of Williams College, who collected the types during his expedition to Peru in 1876-1877. 
#>  - B. c. occidentalis (Latin) refers to the western distribution of this species. 
#>  - The genus was named after the Latin word boa, meaning "large [water] snake." Linnaeus obviously did not know whether this species lived in water or not.  However, Fretey 2019 stated that it stems from Latin bos, ‘cow’; ‘kind of snake’ because it feeds first by sucking cows according to Pliny the elder (Liber 8.14). 
#> 
reptSearch("Boa constrictor", getRef = TRUE)
#> Species:
#>  - Boa constrictor LINNAEUS, 1758 
#> 
#> Higher Taxa:
#>  - Boidae (Boinae), Henophidia, Alethinophidia, Serpentes, Squamata (snakes) 
#> 
#> Subspecies:
#>  - Boa constrictor atlantica GONZALEZ, LIMA, PASSOS & SILVA 2024 
#>  - Boa constrictor constrictor LINNAEUS 1758 
#>  - Boa constrictor longicauda PRICE & RUSSO 1991 
#>  - Boa constrictor occidentalis PHILIPPI 1873 
#>  - Boa constrictor ortonii COPE 1877 
#> 
#> Common Names:
#>  - E: Boa Constrictor (color morphs: albino, Anery, Blood, Camel, Coral Albino, Leopard, Leucistic, Pearl, Prodigy, Squaretail, Arabesque, Salmon, jaguar, Jungle, Marron, Motley, Onyx, Roswell, Fire, Inca, IMG, Pink, Avalanche, Blizzard, Ghost, Hytec, Moonglow, Paradigm, Pewter, Paradigm, Snow, Sunglow, Sunset, 
#>  - G: Abgottschlange 
#>  - S: Tragavenado, boa, macaurel, sarura, güio, Matacaballos 
#>  - E: Short-Tailed Boa [amarali] 
#>  - E: Red-Tailed Boa Constrictor [constrictor] 
#>  - E: Long-Tailed Boa Constrictor [longicauda] 
#>  - E: Orton’s Boa Constrictor [ortonii] 
#>  - E: Dominican Boa Constrictor [pnebulosa] 
#>  - E: Tet’chien or St. Lucian Boa [orophias] 
#>  - Portuguese: Anaconda, Boiuçu, Cobra-de-Veado, Ctaia, Jauacanga, Jiboia, Jiboia-Branca, Jiboia-Cinzenta, Jiboia-da-Cauda-Vermelha, Jiboia-do-Cerrado, Kuong-Kuong, Salamanta-Boi, Suaçu 
#>  - E: Atlantic Boa [atlantica] 
#>  - P: Jiboia Atlântica [atlantica] 
#>  - E: Argentine Boa Constrictor [occidentalis]

#> Distribution:
#>  - Colombia (Valle del Cauca), Venezuela (Merida [HR 27: 88], Isla Margarita), Guyana, French French Guiana, Suriname, Peru (Pasco etc.), Bolivia, Brazil (Amapá, Pará, Rondonia, Roraima, Bahia, Sergipe, RO, Amazonas, Pará, Pernambuco, Paraíba, Distrito Federal, São Paulo, Rio de Janeiro, Paraná, Piauí, Mato Grosso, Goiás, S Ceará, Rio Grande do Norte), Argentina, Paraguay 
#>  - Trinidad, Tobago, Antilles, e.g. Martinique, Aruba (introduced); Antigua (sub-fossil only), elevation (Honduras): 0-1370 m 
#>  - USA (introduced to Florida) 
#>  - amarali (invalid): SE Bolivia (Beni), S Brazil (S Mato Grosso, Goias, Mato Grosso do Sul, Sao Paulo, Roraima, Bahia), N Paraguay; Type locality: Sao Paulo, Brazil. 
#>  - atlantica: Brazil (Rio de Janeiro, Espírito Santo) 
#>  - constrictor: Type locality: “Indiis” 
#>  - eques: Peru (Piura). Type locality: coastal city of Paita and vicinity, Peru. 
#>  - longicauda: N Peru; Type locality: region around Tumbes, Tumbes Province, N Peru. 
#>  - melanogaster: Ecuador (Morona Santiago, Napo); Type locality: Rio Yaupi, Morona Santiago, Ecuador. 
#>  - occidentalis: Paraguay, Argentina (Mendoza, San Luis, Cordoba, La Pampa, Santiago del Estero), SE Bolivia; Type locality: Mendoza and San Juan, Argentina. 
#>  - ortonii: NW Peru (La Libertad, Cajamarca, Lambayeque, Piura; Type locality: Chilete (Cajamarca), west of Pacasmayo, Peru. 
#> 
#> Reproduction:
#>  - ovoviviparous; Booth et al. (2010) provide evidence for parthenogenesis in B. constrictor. 
#> 
#> Types:
#>  - Syntypes: NRM (= NHRM) 10 and NHRM 20001; NRS (= paratypes fide BONNY 2007) 
#>  - Holotype: MCZ 16700, paratypes: UMMZ, FMNH, AMNH [amarali] 
#>  - Holotype: MCZ 176002, subadult male; paratypes: MCZ, RMP [longicauda] 
#>  - Holotype: UMMZ 172680 [melanogaster] 
#>  - Holotype: ANSP 11402 [ortonii]

#>  - Holotype: unlocated fide McDiarmid et al., 1999, Reynolds & Henderson 2018) [occidentalis] 
#> 
#> Diagnosis:
#>  - Diagnosis (constrictor in Honduras): “Boa constrictor differs from all other Honduran snakes by the combination of having enlarged ventral scales that do not extend the entire width of the venter, no enlarged scales on the top of the head, mostly entire subcaudal scales, smooth dorsal scales in more than 60 rows at midbody, a huge adult size, and in lacking labial pits.” (McCranie 2011: 61) 
#>  - Unfortunately we had to temporarily remove additional information as this was scraped by multiple AI companies who sell that data to their customers. These details, e.g. detailed descriptions or comparisons (about 3414 characters) are available for collaborators and contributors. Please contact us for details. 
#> 
#> Comment:
#>  - Synonymy: Boa constrictor melanogaster Langhammer 1983 is a nomen dubium fide Price & Russo 1991. It’s type locality is “Ecuador, Morona-Santiago, nr. Río Yaupi Catholic Mission, upstream from Ró Santiago, Jivaro Indians, Holotype: UMMZ. Synonymy partly after STIMSON 1969. We follow Reynolds (2025) in recognizing B. atlantica as a synonym or subspecies of B. constrictor, given the poor documentation and justification in Gonzalez et al. 2024. 
#>  - Subspecies: Hynková et al. (2010) and others suggested that B. c. imperator may be a full species. If so, they also suggested that it would comprise all populations of the Central American clade, including B. c. sabogae and B. c. longicauda. Hynkova et al. found no molecular support for the distinction between the nominotypic subspecies and B. c. amarali. Hynkova et al. did not analyze all (sub-) species, e.g. orophias or nebulosa. If B. atlantica is treated as species, B. occidentalis needs to be treated as species too. However, both could be treated as subspecies of B. constrictor too. See phylogeny in Gonzalez et al. 2024. 
#>  - Crother et al. (2009) have found a snake shed in Manitoba, Canada, which was identified by DNA sequencing as most likely coming from Boa constrictor. 
#>  - Genome: The Boa constrictor genome has been sequenced by Vicoso et al. (2013). 
#>  - Distribution: B. c. constrictor s.l. only occurs in South America; all other reports from Central America and the Caribbean represent subspecies (now other species). Hence not anymore in Mexico (Tamaulipas, Quéretaro, Veracruz, Puebla, Jalisco, Hidalgo), Belize, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, Panama. Not in Yucatan state (Mexico), fide Gonzalez-Sanchez et al. 2017. See maps in Bonny 2007. Distribution: Not listed for San Luis Potosí by Lemos-Espinal et al. 2018 (checklist SLP). Not in Morelos fide Lemos-Espinal 2020 (where it is replaced by B. sigma). See also map in Nogueira et al. 2019 for South America. See map in Gonzalez et al. 2024 for map of B. atlantica. 
#>  - Relative abundance in Honduras: rare 
#>  - Type species: Boa constrictor LINNAEUS 1758: 215 is the type species of the genus Boa LINNAEUS 1758: 214. 
#>  - Type genus. Boa Linnaeus 1758 is the type genus of the family Boidae (sensu Pyron et al. 2014). The famly (sensu Pyron et al. 2014) contains the following genera: Boa, Chilabothrus, Corallus, Epicrates, Eunectes. 
#>  - Karyotypes: Viana et al. 2020 present karyotypes for Boa constrictor and other boids. 
#>  - Habitat: partly arboreal (Harrington et al. 2018). 
#>  - Extinct species (genus Boa): B. blanchardensis Bochaton & Bailon 2018 
#>  - Chresonymy (atlantica): after Gonzalez et al. 2024, see there also for references. 
#>  - NCBI taxonID: 499170 [occidentalis] 
#> 
#> Etymology:
#>  - Named after the Latin word constrictus, meaning "to constrict or contract." 
#>  - B. c. atlantica was named after the Atlantic coast but mainly the Atlantic Forest ecoregion, the homeland of several endemic species, including this new Boa. 
#>  - B. c. longicauda was apparently named after its long tail, from Latin cauda = tail. 
#>  - B. c. ortonii was named after Named after Prof. James Orton, of Williams College, who collected the types during his expedition to Peru in 1876-1877. 
#>  - B. c. occidentalis (Latin) refers to the western distribution of this species. 
#>  - The genus was named after the Latin word boa, meaning "large [water] snake." Linnaeus obviously did not know whether this species lived in water or not.  However, Fretey 2019 stated that it stems from Latin bos, ‘cow’; ‘kind of snake’ because it feeds first by sucking cows according to Pliny the elder (Liber 8.14). 
#>
